title: Why do people claim that Native Americans came here 15,000 years ago? If the current Native Americans descended from later migrations with better weapons, who killed most of the previous American tribes? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Some ignorant, racist and romanticized or mythologized replies here and some decent, honest accurate replies. Native Peoples of the Americas go back 20,000 to 30,000 years that evidence can be found. That is enough “time” to be considered “Indigenous” but these days any little leverage or a little nugget of “information” to back political spouting off that, “We are all immigrants to America” or “All people migrated from somewhere” will continue until the aliens (ET’s) land. So, the argument will continue indefinitely. Americans don’t want to feel guilt and so nation building mythologies have been created from Columbus (who had nothing to do with the United States) to the Founding Fathers to Manifest Destiny to Cowboys & Indians, whatever. So while these folks argue over who and what is American, they can not comprehend or deal with realities on the ground. Native populations have been walking, moving and yes, migrating, up & down the continents for thousands of years, which “beats” the Euro-American presence of a mere 400–200 years (talking North America now). So what is the current argument that immigration or migrant flow has become a problem? America is made up of immigrants from all over the world! So rather it is a political argument and sides are taken, so one side says “America is Full & your kind need not apply to” the other side which says “What about our founding principles as written in the founding documents & espoused on the Statute of Liberty?” Peoples moved and migrated and were forced to move or were assimilated in Europe, Asia and Africa too. There was no White Race or White Nation, but English, French, German, Spanish, Italian, Greek, Russian, Nordic, Slavic all related or not, who became neighbors or nationals or foreigners within Europe until technical innovations and plagues or disease and industrial revolution compelled peoples to move & migrate. So has the United States of America become a White Nation only for whites & Christians? That argument goes against the great melting pot theory (religiously taught in nation-building myths in all schools), so we quickly see people disavowing that concept for another that goes against mythology to try and rationalize new agendas. The Know Nothing Party was the first ‘America First’ anti-immigrant one-issue party and if course considered themselves “Native” Americans. (See the film, Gangs of New York.) In their answers, Sandbrook and Borreson state grounded and cogent research as to habitation of the Americas. Our people’s oral traditions about migrations and stories about the land are sometimes proven true with modern discoveries. Our routes have been underwater since our ancestors hugged the shores but certain areas were never submerged. Yes, waves of peoples created varying conditions of cultural conflict but the Idea of America has always been wide open so people moved by choice or by being compelled. Even now, “America’s Openness” is a feature touted by both sides, until it’s not and it’s too crowded and we got to ship people away or turn them back. Unless they’re from Norway or England? History says people move and nations fall and countries change. Why not say we are all in this together and be ahead of the curve? Kind of like flatten the curve and make it last longer, or, ride the curve high then fall fast as Empire collapses.

Biogenetic evidence suggests that most indigenous populations of the Americas derive from populations which crossed into Alaska/Yukon somewhere between 30,000 and 22,000 years ago. There is evidence for multiple back migrations, and break-out from Alaska/Yukon past the Cordillera/Laurentian ice sheets no less than 16,500 years ago. There were certainly later migration waves such as the Thule migration into the Canadian high arctic circa ~1,000 CE, and they apparently did displace the earlier Dorsett people. And when the ice free corridor opened between the Laurentide and Cordilleran ice sheets some 12,000 years ago, there was apparently another migration wave from Alaska-Yukon (as evident from XRF analysis of obsidian artefacts, linguistics, and the great difference between Alberta and Clovis points), and dispersed into the interior possibly as far as Mexico. Also, this isn’t so much something that people think as archaeologists. I’m pretty sure most people think nothing of this at all.
